abstract.p: Milton D Ottensoser letter, commenting on May 14 article on housing options for the elderly, notes certain risks people run in transferring a primary residence to children to reduce one's wealth for estate-tax purposes

block.p: The lead article in the May 14 Real Estate section, ''The Elderly Face Housing Choices,'' was an excellent summary of options offered to the elderly for estate and Medicaid planning.

One caveat (to use a favorite word of lawyers) to any person considering transferring a primary residence to children to reduce one's wealth for estate-tax purposes, rather than for nursing home/Medicaid purposes:
The lead article in the May 14 Real Estate section, ''The Elderly Face Housing Choices,'' was an excellent summary of options offered to the elderly for estate and Medicaid planning.

One caveat (to use a favorite word of lawyers) to any person considering transferring a primary residence to children to reduce one's wealth for estate-tax purposes, rather than for nursing home/Medicaid purposes:

Even if capital gains and gift-tax issues are overcome, one should not ignore the common scenario of prudent, conservative senior citizens transferring a major asset -- their home -- to members of a younger generation who statistically are far more likely than their elders to get involved in uninsured or underinsured lawsuits, messy divorces, bankruptcies resulting from overspending or from a business going sour, and numerous other catastrophes.
If this occurs, grandma's house (along with her status as an occupant) goes on the table as an asset of her imprudent or unlucky child.
A far less risky course to reduce wealth for estate-tax purposes is to transfer to children nonprimary residence assets such as stocks and bonds.
